Authors:
Eduardo Perez Pazos, Margarita Villegas Rios, Roberto
Garibay Orijel, Rodolfo Salas Lizana
Title:
Two new species of Clavulina and the first record of
Clavulina reae from temperate Abies religiosa forests in central
Mexico
Keywords:
Cantharellales, Clavulinaceae, coral fungi, species
complex, taxonomy
Abstract:
Clavulina is an ectomycorrhizal genus of macroscopic
basidiomycetes, mostly with clavarioid basidiomata, distributed
worldwide. The most commonly reported species are C. amethystina, C.
cinerea, C. coralloides, and C. rugosa, which form a species complex in
temperate ecosystems. In this work, we describe two new species for the
genus: C. mahiscolorata and C. parvispora; these species show great
resemblance to previously described species. Nevertheless, they
represent new lineages distributed in temperate forests from central
Mexico. We present a geographical range redistribution of C. reae, which
displays great macro-morphological variation regarding basidiome
branching rank, colors, and tip shape. We provide macromorphological,
micromorphological, and habitat data for each species, as well as rDNA
ITS and LSU, and RPB2 sequences. Our findings highlight an
underestimation of richness in temperate ecosystems, as a consequence of
misallocation of common epithets to undescribed taxa. The designation of
neotypes for temperate species of Clavulina is urgent, in order to
delimit species concepts for the genus.
